stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain how the body regulates pH?

prompts.text: What are the normal values for arterial blood gases?
expectedKeyFacts: pH: 7.35-7.45 (hydrogen ion concentration 35-45 nmol/L)
PaCO₂: 4.5-6.0 kPa (34-46 mmHg)
PaO₂: 10.5-13.5 kPa (80-100 mmHg) breathing room air
Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 22-28 mmol/L
Base excess: -2 to +2 mmol/L
Standard bicarbonate: measured at PaCO₂ 5.3 kPa

prompts.text: Explain the three main buffering systems in the body.
expectedKeyFacts: Bicarbonate buffer: CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻
Most important extracellular buffer, regulated by lungs and kidneys
Protein buffers: haemoglobin (most important), albumin
Phosphate buffer: H₂PO₄⁻ ⇌ HPO₄²⁻ + H⁺, important in urine
Henderson-Hasselbalch equation: pH = pKa + log([HCO₃⁻]/[H₂CO₃])
Respiratory compensation: minutes (change ventilation)
Renal compensation: days (excrete/retain H⁺ and HCO₃⁻)

prompts.text: A patient has pH 7.28, PaCO₂ 7.5 kPa, HCO₃⁻ 24 mmol/L, base excess 0. What is the acid-base disturbance?
expectedKeyFacts: Acidaemia (pH <7.35)
Raised PaCO₂ — respiratory acidosis
Normal bicarbonate and base excess — acute, uncompensated
Causes: hypoventilation, respiratory depression, airway obstruction
If chronic: expect metabolic compensation with raised HCO₃⁻
For every 1 kPa rise in PaCO₂, HCO₃⁻ rises 1 mmol/L acutely, 4 mmol/L chronically
Management: treat underlying cause, improve ventilation

prompts.text: How does the kidney handle acid-base balance?
expectedKeyFacts: Reabsorbs all filtered HCO₃⁻ in proximal tubule
Secretes H⁺ in distal tubule and collecting duct
H⁺ buffered by ammonia (NH₃ + H⁺ → NH₄⁺) and phosphate
Type A intercalated cells secrete H⁺ via H⁺-ATPase
Type B intercalated cells secrete HCO₃⁻ in alkalosis
Generates new HCO₃⁻ for systemic use
Compensation takes 3-5 days
Can excrete acid urine (pH 4.5-5.5) or alkaline (pH 8)

prompts.text: What is the anion gap and how is it useful?
expectedKeyFacts: Anion gap = (Na⁺ + K⁺) - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻), or Na⁺ - (Cl⁻ + HCO₃⁻)
Normal 12-16 mmol/L (without K⁺) or 16-20 mmol/L (with K⁺)
Represents unmeasured anions (albumin, phosphate, sulphate, lactate)
High anion gap metabolic acidosis: MUDPILES (Methanol, Uraemia, DKA, Paraldehyde, Iron/Isoniazid, Lactic acidosis, Ethylene glycol, Salicylates)
Normal anion gap acidosis: GI losses (diarrhoea), RTA, Addison's
Corrected for albumin: add 2.5 to AG for every 10 g/L drop in albumin
Useful for differentiating causes of metabolic acidosis

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me how you interpret an arterial blood gas — what is your systematic approach?
keyFacts: Normal pH 7.35-7.45, PaCO₂ 4.5-6.0 kPa, HCO₃⁻ 22-28 mmol/L
Metabolic acidosis: low HCO₃⁻, negative base excess
High AG: lactic acidosis, DKA, uraemia
Kidney: reabsorbs HCO₃⁻, secretes H⁺, generates new HCO₃⁻

scoringGuidance.pass: States normal ABG values, explains buffering systems and Henderson-Hasselbalch, interprets ABG correctly identifying primary disturbance and compensation, describes renal acid handling, understands anion gap and its use; stronger candidates discuss compensation formulas and corrected anion gap
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows some normal values but incomplete, mentions buffers but mechanism unclear, can identify acidosis but compensation vague, aware of anion gap but interpretation limited
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot state normal ABG values, does not understand buffering or compensation, cannot interpret ABG, unaware of anion gap concept or renal acid handling
